item.title: Ukraine nuclear plant: Russia in control after shelling
item.description: Authorities say the facility - the largest plant in Europe - is safe and radiation levels are normal.

item.title: War in Ukraine: Russia restricts access to BBC in media crackdown
item.description: Restrictions are placed on several broadcasters as a law makes it an offence to spread "fake" information.

item.title: Former Ukraine president: Don't trust or be afraid of Putin
item.description: "You cannot kill Ukrainian soul" says Petro Poroshenko, the former president of Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine war is economic catastrophe, warns World Bank
item.description: The war will cut growth and push up living costs globally, the World Bank tells the BBC.

item.title: Metal price rise will make canned food more expensive, says LME chief
item.description: UK shoppers are likely to face higher prices, the head of the London Metal Exchange says.

item.title: Ros Atkins on...Russian gas and oil
item.description: Ros Atkins looks at how Russian gas and oil connects to war in Ukraine, and EU efforts to cut ties with Russia.

item.title: Moon crash: Discarded rocket part to hit Moon in hours, say scientists
item.description: The space junk has confused experts but is soon to crash at high speed leaving a crater on the Moon.

item.title: Birmingham: Starmer hails new Erdington MP as 'champion of working people'
item.description: Paulette Hamilton is Birmingham's first black MP in an election held after the death of Jack Dromey.

item.title: Covid: All rules in Wales could be axed on 28 March
item.description: Mask, self-isolation laws and free mass testing to end as Wales sets out plans to lift all measures.

item.title: Ukraine invasion: Labour calls for emergency visas to help refugees
item.description: The home secretary is urged to do more for refugees as she launches a family visa scheme in Poland.

item.title: 'Dismissive' police force pays rape complainant damages
item.description: The woman says one police officer treated her like she was "just being silly".

item.title: Son of accused 6 January rioters testifies in court
item.description: “If you turn me in, you’re a traitor and traitors get shot,” Guy Reffitt is alleged to have told his son.

item.title: 'I am Mr McAdams': TV anchor Rahul Shivshankar yells at wrong man on Ukraine live
item.description: Times Now editor-in-chief Rahul Shivshankar only realised his mistake when his perplexed guest spoke up.

item.title: WATCH: Russian TV staff walk off set after final broadcast
item.description: Channel TV Rain stops operating after coming under pressure over its coverage of the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine: How might the war end? Five scenarios
item.description: What are some of the possible scenarios that politicians and military planners are examining?

item.title: Economic Crime Bill: What is it and will it find Putin's loot?
item.description: Will the Economic Crime Bill really tackle Putin's money - or is it too little, too late?

item.title: Ukraine conflict: Before and after images reveal Russian destruction
item.description: These images show the aftermath of devastating Russian missile attacks on civilian areas across Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine conflict: Your guide to understanding day eight
item.description: Cities under relentless bombardment. Here's what you need to know after day eight of the war.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: How much trade does Russia do with China?
item.description: The two countries have a growing economic partnership, but sanctions on Russia could complicate it.

item.title: What evidence is there of cluster bombs being used?
item.description: Evidence of one attack in the city of Kharkiv has led to allegations of war crimes against Russia.

item.title: Ukraine maps: Russians take nuclear plant but Kyiv advance slows
item.description: Russia seizes power plant in Ukraine as the assault on the country intensifies.

item.title: Why is Russia invading Ukraine and what does Putin want?
item.description: What you should know about the reasons given for Russia's full-scale military assault on Ukraine.

item.title: What sanctions could still be imposed on Russia?
item.description: The measures are tougher than anything Vladimir Putin has faced. But more could be coming.

item.title: 'Putin has to be stopped' - the Britons preparing to fight in Ukraine
item.description: We talk to some of the people responding to President Zelensky's appeal for foreigners to join in the defence of his country

item.title: Ukraine: Watching the war on Russian TV - a whole different story
item.description: The war in Ukraine has led to outrage in the West, but in Russia TV viewers see a very different story.

item.title: Ukraine conflict: Mum in Poland takes in fleeing families
item.description: Joanna is opening her home in Poland to Ukraine refugees seeking shelter after reaching the border.

item.title: How many nuclear weapons does Russia have?
item.description: A look at Russia's nuclear arsenal and basic guide to nuclear weapons and their destructive power

item.title: Glastonbury 2022: Paul McCartney, Billie Eilish and Kendrick Lamar to headline
item.description: Sir Paul McCartney will top the bill on the Pyramid Stage, a week after his 80th birthday.

item.title: Ukraine: On board a Nato surveillance plane monitoring Russian activity
item.description: The BBC has been given rare access to a surveillance flight on the Polish border with Ukraine and Belarus.

item.title: Europe's largest nuclear plant shelled in Ukraine
item.description: Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant is hit during shelling in Ukraine.

item.title: The Papers: 'Worst is yet to come' as Russian attacks escalate
item.description: The front pages reflect fears for Ukrainian civilians as the bombardment of cities continues.

item.title: Rufford Lane ford: Millions watch cars get stuck in deep water
item.description: Videos of cars getting stuck in a Nottinghamshire ford are watched by millions around the world.

item.title: Quiz of the week: Who had the year's most played record?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: Storms uncover 200-year-old boat on Portrush beach
item.description: The remains of the fishing boat were found by two dog walkers, who initially thought it was debris.

item.title: Drone captures destruction in one Ukrainian town
item.description: Footage shows how flats and Russian military vehicles were destroyed in Borodyanka.

item.title: Ukraine conflict: Telling my children why dad joined the war - Kyiv mother
item.description: Olena Gnes says it is important for her children to know their father joined Ukraine's defence unit.

item.title: In pictures: Ukraine donations pile high across the UK
item.description: Volunteers are working everywhere from salons to car parks - but some have been overwhelmed.

item.title: Ukraine: Why has Russia's 64km convoy near Kyiv stopped moving?
item.description: Russian forces advancing on the Ukrainian capital appear to have stalled, US and UK officials say.

item.title: Ukraine: Amateurs dig in to fight Russian troops from Kyiv forests
item.description: Deep in the forests outside Ukraine's capital Kyiv amateur fighters prepare for the battlefield.

item.title: Ukraine: The race to save the country's artistic treasures
item.description: As the Russian invasion continues, efforts to protect Ukraine's cultural heritage are stepped up.

item.title: 'My city is being shelled, but my mum in Russia won’t believe me'
item.description: These Ukrainians say their Russian relatives only trust the narratives they see on TV at home.

item.title: Winter Paralympics: The lowdown on being disabled in China
item.description: From an outrageous poet to an "atmosphere of fear", get the lowdown on disabled life in China.

item.title: Mental health in Runcorn: 'We're just two lads who want to help'
item.description: Keelan and Paul set up a coffee club in memory of their friend Curt, who died after taking drugs.

item.title: The shipping giant banking on a greener fuel
item.description: Maersk has ordered 12 huge ships that run on methanol rather than marine oil fuel.

item.title: Germans welcome Ukrainian refugees by train: 'It could have been us'
item.description: As Ukrainians fleeing war pour into Berlin, they find families waiting to offer them shelter.

item.title: Riky Rick: South African rap star who died aged 34
item.description: Riky Rick was one of South Africa's top rappers but there was always a hidden side to his fame.

item.title: How many violent attacks and sexual assaults on women are there?
item.description: The deaths of Sarah Everard, Sabina Nessa, and others highlights the dangers women face.

item.title: How many refugees have fled Ukraine and where are they going?
item.description: The EU says up to four million people may try to escape the war in Ukraine.

item.title: The firms pulling back from Russia
item.description: Reputational risk and practical difficulties are making it harder to do business in the country.

item.title: Ukraine conflict: Reunions and warm welcomes for refugees at Berlin train station
item.description: Crowds of volunteers were there to help the new arrivals, with many offering the refugees rooms in their houses.

item.title: NHS Tracker: How is the NHS in your area coping this winter?
item.description: Winter and Covid are putting the NHS under severe strain, find out what's happening in your area.

item.title: Covid: How could the pandemic have affected your brain?
item.description: Scientists say uncertainty and disruption have affected people even if they haven't had Covid.

item.title: The manager who beat Real Madrid 'not afraid' as he leaves Europa League side to fight in Ukraine
item.description: Six months ago Yuriy Vernydub was winning at Real Madrid, one week ago he was managing in the Europa League. Now, he is in Ukraine and ready to fight.

item.title: 'Not fair' that Abramovich is selling Chelsea - Newcastle co-owner Staveley
item.description: Newcastle co-owner Amanda Staveley says it is unfair that Roman Abramovich has decided to sell Chelsea following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Sunday league to Test debut in three years - rapid rise of West Indies keeper Da Silva
item.description: West Indies wicketkeeper Joshua da Silva tells BBC Sport about his rapid rise from Surrey league cricket to Test regular.

item.title: Can Sancho finally show Man City what they missed out on?
item.description: Jadon Sancho will finally get the chance to play at Etihad Stadium when Manchester United travel to his former club Manchester City on Sunday, writes BBC Sport's Simon Stone.

item.title: Sivakov switches cycling nationality from Russia to France
item.description: Ineos Grenadiers rider Pavel Sivakov changes his cycling nationality from Russian to French.

item.title: Ex-England captain Burgess fined & suspended by NRL for drug use and threats
item.description: Former England captain Sam Burgess has been fined and suspended by Australia's National Rugby League for breaching rules including drug use and threatening behaviour.

item.title: What are the latest rules for face coverings and masks?
item.description: Rules around face coverings are easing across the UK but they are still required in some settings.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid boosters: Who will get a fourth dose?
item.description: Care workers in England won't need to be vaccinated, and some people will get a fourth Covid jab.

item.title: What are the UK's 'Living with Covid' plans?
item.description: All legal Covid restrictions in England have ended, and Scotland is also removing its legal requirements.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: What are the self-isolation rules in England and the rest of the UK?
item.description: People with Covid in England are no longer legally required to self-isolate, although it is still recommended.

item.title: When will free Covid tests end in England?
item.description: The government is scrapping free Covid tests for most people in England.

item.title: What Covid tests do I still need to travel abroad?
item.description: From Friday, fully vaccinated people travelling to the UK no longer have to take any Covid tests.

item.title: How will the vulnerable be protected from Covid? And other questions
item.description: The government has announced the end of all Covid restrictions in England.
